11 December 2014 â€¢ 3 min read

In Summer 1999 I met a girl. We hooked up for a bit and it didnâ€™t really work out. But then in Autumn 1999 I met another girl. That went much better. :)

The Sopranos and Family Guy both debuted on US television, Melissa â€œattacked the internetâ€, the Columbine massacre happened, Jill Dando was shot dead on her doorstep, The Phantom Menace umâ€¦ happened, Napster debuted, we had a total solar eclipse which I peered at through the clouds on a rooftop in Soho, having landed my first London job, Apple released the G4 and Sega released the Dreamcast.

It was thank you and goodnight to (among, as always, many others) Dusty Springfield, Stanley Kubrick, Yehudi Menuhin, Little Ern, Dirk Bogarde, Bones (DeForest Kelly), Q (Desmond Llewelyn), Screaming Lord Sutch and the mighty, mighty Oliver Reed.

On millennium night I played a covers gig in Hastings, where for the first half we partied like it was 1999, because it was. And then it wasnâ€™t. But we carried on anyway.

Honourable mentions

Buckcherry - Buckcherry

Iâ€™ve written much about Buckcherry as it is, but this was their debut album. I missed it at the time and came to it later, and still to this day prefer the followup Time Bomb, but this is still a righteous rocking album. Proper raw rock and roll. Top track: â€œLawless And Luluâ€

Ludovico Einaudi - Eden Roc

Iâ€™ve only quite recently discovered the minimalist stylings of Ludo, but when I heard him on Classic FM I rushed out and bought just about everything of his I could find. Minimal classical, nothing too challenging, perhaps a little anodyne for some, but I love it. Top track: â€œDue Tramontiâ€

Powerman 5000 - Tonight the Stars Revolt!

No idea where I first heard â€œNobodyâ€™s Realâ€ but when I did it made me want more, and this is such a cracking album. Snarly punk-industrial-metal (nu, perhapsâ€¦ shudderâ€¦) and great fun throughout. Top track: â€œNobodyâ€™s Realâ€

Red Hot Chili Peppers - Californication

This was the Chilisâ€™ first studio album in four years, and marked the return of John Frusciante on the six-string twangplank. It remains their best-selling album ever, though for my money itâ€™s slightly bettered by 2002â€™s By The Way. Still great though. Top track: â€œScar Tissueâ€

Stereophonics - Performance and Cocktails

The 'phonics were everywhere in 1999. You couldnâ€™t move for â€œThe Bartender and the Thiefâ€, â€œJust Lookingâ€ and â€œPick a Part Thatâ€™s Newâ€, and that was because theyâ€™re ace songs. The rest of the album is just as great, if not greater. Top track: â€œPick A Part Thatâ€™s Newâ€

And the winner isâ€¦

Underworld - Beaucoup Fish

King of Snake, King of Snake.

Tina lives in Berlin, her voice so seldom on my machine.

Etc.

Again, I was late to the Underworld party, but my mate trying hard to get me to listen to something that didnâ€™t at least feature a fast lead guitarist must have finally broken through because one day I saw the light. I wonâ€™t lie to you, alcohol probably played a part. This is splendid music to get at least partially off your ordinary face to. In fact I think Iâ€™d been listening to this album for a number of years before I realised that the lyrics to â€œPush Upstairsâ€ and â€œPush Downstairsâ€ are the same, and that one is a downtempo moody version of the other. Which is quite clever, though I obviously wasnâ€™t.

Intelligent, dancey electronica that isnâ€™t afraid to go dark occasionally all carried along by Karl Hydeâ€™s swirling stream-of-consciousness lyrics.

And, to quote Rufus (from Bill & Ted), itâ€™s excellent for dancing.

Top tracks: â€œPush Upstairsâ€, â€œKing Of Snakeâ€, â€œCupsâ€

Turkey of the Year

Mr. Big - Get Over It

Oh dear. For me Mr. Big needed Paul Gilbertâ€™s sense of humour running through their music to make it listenable, and his replacement Richie Kotzen - while an absolutely incredible musician - is pretty po-faced, and the band lost something vital at this point.
